data.text:
‘Death on The 16th Fairway,’ which premieres at The Media Theatre June 5-16 and is part of Media Borough’s Golf Month Celebration due to Delaware County’s hosting of the US Open this year. Conceived and written by avid golfer and investment adviser Art Leahy, it is the story of Ryan’s Way Country Club, an exclusive golf, dining, and fitness facility. The show is a fictional creation based on Leahy’s behind-the-scenes experience as a golf club member and financial professional. In the show, being produced during the US Open held at Merion Golf Club in Ardmore. a body is discovered at Fader’s Bog on the course’s signature hole, Hole 16. The story takes off from that point, with interesting – and, at times, humorous – characters as everyone tries to figure out what has happened during the Ryan’s Way Country Club 50th Anniversary Celebration. The cast is made up of local actors seen frequently on area stages. John Baxter, seen in ‘Annie’ and ‘Jekyll and Hyde: The Musical’ at The Media Theatre as well as ‘The Jungle Book’, will portray the role of Alistair Lane. Media resident and well known thespian and educator Jim Conte will appear as President Woods. The Media Theatre’s own Roger Ricker will play Bogey The Bartender. Emmy Award-winning sportscaster Jim Kelly will narrate the production on June 9. Several performances are designated as fundraisers for various non-profit organizations, including The Media Theatre. At the performance on June 9, as part of the Autism Speaks fundraiser, Ryan Leahy will play the role of the bartender. For more information or tickets, call The Media Theatre at 610-891-0100 or visitmediatheatre.org.

The final show of Forge Theatre’s fiftieth season, and the final production in its First Avenue location, will be the lively Broadway musical hit ‘The Drowsy Chaperone.’ A joyful send-up of 1920’s musicals, this play-within-a-play comes to life in the living room of a musical aficionado. ‘The Drowsy Chaperone’ is crammed full with every gag and gimmick from the golden age of musical theatre and features tap dancing, large production numbers, roller skating, plus an airplane onstage. Performance dates are June 7, 8, 14, 15, 16, 21, 22, 23, 27, 28, 29. Evening performances are at 8 p.m., Sunday matinees at 2 p.m. Admission is $15 for adults, $12 for youth under 18. Reservations are strongly recommended and can either be made on Forge’s website at www.forgetheatre.org or by calling 610-935-1920.

Shakespeare’s ‘Much Ado About Nothing’ will be performed outdoors at the Frank Stephens Memorial Theater (aka The Field Theater) adjacent to the Arden Green in Arden, Del. by the Arden Shakespeare Gild. The cast includes many favorite actors from previous shows as well as a number of talented newcomers. Original music is provided by John King, who also takes on the role of the wise and genial Friar. Rebecca Fisher sings as Balthasar, and musicians Emily Loney, Melanie Riblett, Rachel Loney and Sam Arthur provide beautiful harmonies and subversive undertones. Performances are June 7, 8, 13-15, 21 and 22 at 7:30 p.m., plus a matinee on Sunday, June 9 at 4 p.m. Performances move to the Gild Hall in the event of rain. Call 302-475-3126 to reserve your tickets, Prices are $10 for general admission, $5 for children 12 and under and $5 for all matinee tickets. For more information, go to www.ardenshakespearegild.org.

Life is a cabaret! Get ready for some toe-tapping musical entertainment as the talented local performers from the Jennersville Y’s new theatre company present, ‘Broadway Through the Decades,’ a salute to Broadway’s most beloved musicals. The premier performance will be held at Deerfield Golf Club, 507 Thompson Station Road, Newark, Delaware, on June 14 at 7 p.m. and includes a selection of gourmet appetizers and desserts prepared by celebrity chef Paul O’Toole. On June 15, the performance moves to Chester County Technical College in West Grove with family-friendly light refreshments and desserts. Performance times are 2 and 7 p.m. Broadway favorites include songs from ‘South Pacific,’ ‘West Side Story,’ ‘The Music Man, Chicago,’ ‘Les Miserables,’ ‘Wicked,’ ‘Hair Spray’ and other popular show tunes. Tickets are available at the Jennersville Y, 880 W. Baltimore Pike, West Grove or at the door. The cost for the June 14 performance is $30. The cost for the June 15 performance is $15 for adults and $8 for children 12 and under. For more information, contact Laura Woods, theatre director at 610-869-9622, ext. 2538 or lwoods@ymcabwv.org.

The Children’s Theater at The Players Club of Swarthmore closes its season with the classic ‘Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs.’ This captivating, imaginative treatment of the popular Grimm Brothers tale brings to life the popular characters of Snow White, the Seven Dwarfs, the wicked Queen and the magical, talking Mirror. In this delightful adaptation – with a grown up cast – there’s dancing, plotting, heart break and redemption, plus some comic relief throughout. Director Jim Carroll has assembled a talented, local cast from Wallingford, Springfield, Media, Boothwyn, Havertown, Merion, West Chester, Norristown and Philadelphia to bring this story to life. ‘Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs’ runs Friday, June 21 at 7 p.m.; Saturday, June 22 at 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.; Sunday, June 23 at 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.; Friday, June 28 at 7 p.m.; Saturday, June 29 at 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.; Sunday, June 30 at 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. All of the Children’s Series productions will be performed on The Players Club of Swarthmore’s Raymond W. Smith stage on the second floor. Adult tickets are $10 each and Children under 12 are $8, cash or check only. All children two years of age and under are free. All tickets are sold at the door on the day of the performance. The Players Club of Swarthmore is located at 614 Fairview Road-just off of Route 320. Visit www.pcstheater.org for information on upcoming events, directions, etc.

People’s Light & Theatre presents Bess Wohl’s ‘Barcelona’ running May 29-June 23 on the Steinbright Stage. Jackson Gay directs. People’s Light & Theatre is located at 39 Conestoga Road, Malvern, PA 19355. For tickets call 610.644.3500 or visit PeoplesLight.org. In ‘Barcelona,’ an American woman leaves her own party with a tall, dark stranger – an older Spanish man. Is it a carefree one-night stand or an invitation to danger? This is a scintillating world premiere that takes a funny and seductive look at the politics of who we pretend to be versus who we really are. ‘Barcelona’ is produced as part of a rolling world premiere agreement between People’s Light and The Contemporary American Theater Festival at Shepherds University in Shepherdstown, West Virginia. The play has also been optioned by Olympus Theatricals for a commercial production in London. Barcelona previews on Wednesday, May 29, and Thursday, May 30 at 7:30 pm and Friday, May 31 at 8 pm. The play opens on Saturday, June 1 and runs through Sunday, June 23. Audiences are encouraged to join the artists for a conversation about the production after the Thursday performances on June 6, 13 & 20. Single tickets: $25 – $45. For tickets, call the Box Office at 610.644.3500. Special discounts are available for groups of 10 or more. For more information or to purchase group tickets, call 610.647.1900 x134 or email charles@peopleslight.org.

The Barley Sheaf Players (810 N. Whitford Road, Lionville, PA 19353, www.barleysheaf.org) present ‘I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change.’ The show opened May 31. ‘I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change’ celebrates the mating game as it takes on the truths and myths behind that contemporary conundrum known as ‘the relationship.’ The hilarious and heartfelt songs and skits in this lighthearted romp start with a first date and end in a funeral parlor with various vignettes in between, from break-ups and marriages to birth and parenthood. Act I explores the journey from dating and waiting to love and marriage, while Act II reveals the agonies and triumphs of in-laws and newborns, trips in the family car, and pick-up techniques of the geriatric set. With book and lyrics by Joe Dipietro and music by Jimmy Roberts, both the upbeat and the offbeat are highlighted in songs like ‘Single Man Drought,’ ‘Always a Bridesmaid,’ and ‘He Called Me.’ The show features eight versatile actors with fine voices who portray the over 50 characters in this show, deftly maneuvering from the comedic to the heartfelt. This hilarious revue pays tribute to those who have loved and lost, to those who have fallen on their face at the portal of romance, to those who have dared to ask, ‘What are you doing Saturday night?’ The production is full with a seasoned cast of local actors, including: Erin Anne Bohmaker, Allison Greet, Deb Topka, and Chris Mercury of West Chester; Jamie Brandt Trommelen of Downingtown; Paul Hayward of Wilmington; Kevin Robinson of Pottstown; and Jeremy Wheeler of King of Prussia. Also assisting with the production are Consulting Director Christine Robinson and Stage Manager Tracy Bell of Pottstown; Musical Director Randi Carp of Chester Springs; Choreographer Rose-Marie Abi-Richa of Downingtown; and Technical Directors (mother and daughter team) Karen and Chelsea Barnett of Malvern. Karen Barnett also serves as co-Producer, along with Carolyn Salerno of Downingtown. Schultz also designed the minimalist set, brought to life by Master Carpenter Dave Cowburn of West Grove. ‘I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change’ runs Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m. from May 31 through June 22. Reserved seating is available by calling the box office at 610-363-7075. Please note, ‘I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change’ contains adult themes and language. Consider it a comparable to a movie with a PG-13 rating, which may not be suitable for younger patrons.

The Centre Theater concludes its 20132-13 season with questions of immigration, race and class passionately presented with beautiful accompanying music in ‘Ragtime,’ the musical. The Centre Theater presents, Ragtime, the musical. running May 31 to June 23. The play is performed Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m. in The Centre’s fourth floor space. Tickets are available by calling 610-279-1013. The Tony-winning score by Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty is just as diverse as the melting pot of America itself. It draws upon many musical styles from the ragtime rhythms of Harlem and Tin Pan Alley to the klezmer of the Lower East Side, from bold brass band marches to delicate waltzes, from up-tempo banjo tunes to period parlor songs and expansive anthems. This production is directed by Norristown native Rory Zummo and has a large cast of local and regional actors The Centre Theater is in the Montgomery County Cultural Center at 208 DeKalb Street in Norristown. It is easily reached via routes 202, I-76, I-476 and Ridge Pike. There is plenty of free parking and the theater is one block from Septa’s Norristown Transit Center on the Manayunk/Norristown line. For tickets and more information call 610-279-1013, or purchase online anytime at www.thecentretheater.org.

‘Oliver’ isn’t obvious ‘feel good’ musical fare. It’s the story of an orphaned, workhouse boy who is mistreated then sold, escapes, finds himself in the clutches of a miserly old man (who exploits homeless children and fences the items they steal), becomes entangled with and then threatened by a foreboding villain from the East End, and then witnesses a murder. And yet, this story is actually an uplifting one (spoiler alert: the good guys win!) and has become part of classic entertainment, much like the Wizard of Oz, which appeals in many ways to many sorts of people. ‘Oliver’ runs through June 8. Details and tickets may be obtained at the theater website, www.footlighterstheater.com.

Walnut Street Theatre concludes its landmark 204th season with an all-new production of Broadway and Hollywood’s smash-hit, ‘Grease.’ Directed by Bruce Lumpkin, with choreography by Michelle Gaudette, this musical extravaganza opened on May 22 and runs through July 14 on the WST Mainstage. ‘Grease’ is taking over Philadelphia this summer! Get out your leather jackets, pull on your bobby socks and take a trip to a simpler time with the original high school musical. Danny is the hunky ‘bad boy’ and Sandy is ‘the girl next door.’ They meet and fall in love. But will their different worlds keep them apart? Hear all of the unforgettable songs from the Broadway show and hit movie, including ‘You’re The One That I Want,’ ‘Grease Is The Word,’ ‘Summer Nights,’ ‘Hopelessly Devoted To You,’ and ‘Greased Lightnin’.’ Get ready to hand-jive the night away with the show that’ll make you want to stand up and shout, ‘A-wop-bop-a-loo-bop A-wop-bam-boom!’ For tickets and information, call 215-574-3550 or 800-982-2787. Tickets are also available online 24/7 by visiting www.WalnutStreetTheatre.org or Ticketmaster.

Theatre Horizon’s final production of its Grand Opening 2012-2013 season, ‘Spring Awakening,’ is written by Steven Sater, American playwright, lyricist, and screenwriter, with music by Duncan Sheik, and directed by Barrymore-award winner Matthew Decker, resident director and co-founder of Theatre Horizon. Winner of eight Tony Awards, ‘Spring Awakening’ is an exhilarating rock musical about adolescents colliding with each other and with a world that cannot contain their desires. Set in repressive 19th century Germany, Spring Awakening’s ravishing score by Grammy Award winner Duncan Sheik evokes adolescence in violent bloom. Spring Awakening opened May 23 and runs through Sunday, June 9. Tickets may be purchased through the Theatre Horizon box office by calling 610-283-2230, or online at www.TheatreHorizon.org. Box office hours are Tuesdays – Saturdays from noon to 5 p.m. Discounts are available for students, seniors, and groups of 8 or more. Theatre Horizon is located at 401 DeKalb Street, Norristown 19401.

Walnut Street Theatre’s 2012-2013 Independence Studio on 3 season concludes with a world premiere musical celebration of Dean Martin’s life, ‘DINO! An Evening with Dean Martin at the Latin Casino.’ Written by Armen Pandola and directed by Fran Prisco, the production opened May 2 and continues through June 23 in the Walnut’s Independence Studio on 3. It’s 1978 and Dean Martin is scheduled to perform at the Latin Casino. A severe blizzard blankets the East Coast, and Dino’s band gets stuck out of town. Rather than disappoint his fans, Dean Martin treats them to a special performance as he weaves personal stories through his classic hits, including ‘Ain’t That A Kick In The Head,’ ‘Everybody Loves Somebody’ and ‘That’s Amore.’ For a short while, the man behind the legend reveals the humor, warmth and casual cool that marked his rise from his gritty childhood in Steubenville, Ohio to become one of the biggest legends in entertainment. With effortless charm and style, Nat Chandler returns to the Walnut to play Dean Martin. Walnut audiences will remember Chandler as the title roles in Phantom and Camelot. Tickets are $35 – $45 and are now available at 215-574-3550 or 800-982-2787. Tickets are also available at WalnutStreetTheatre.org or Ticketmaster.com.

Hedgerow Theatre’s Written Word festival will include ‘John Brown’s Body,’ a drama adapted from Stephen Vincent Benet’s poem about the Civil War, from May 25 to June 9; and Love Letters, A.R. Gurney’s evocative, touching, funny play of two lives told through letters to each other, from June 15 to 30. Each performance will also include a reception where there will be refreshments and an opportunity to speak with the actors. Tickets are $20 if purchased in advance or $25 at the door. For reservations, call 610-565-4211, or visit www.hedgerowtheatre.org. Hedgerow Theatre, America’s First Repertory Theatre, is located at 64 Rose Valley Road, in Rose Valley (near Media).

Three retired military men plan one last great adventure in the Philadelphia premiere of ‘Heroes,’ Tom Stoppard’s adaptation of Gerald Sibleyras’ Le Vent Des Peupliers and the final production of Lantern Theater Company’s 2012/13 season. Directed by M. Craig Getting and starring local actors Peter DeLaurier, Mal Whyte and Dan Kern, performances will run May 16 through June 9. Gustave (Kern), Philippe (Whyte) and Henri (DeLaurier) are three World War I heroes plotting an escape from the dictatorial captors and untrustworthy fellow prisoners at their retired soldiers’ home. While hatching their plan for an escape from their back patio to Indochina – or to the poplars on a nearby hill – these once vibrant and virile war heroes struggle with the reality of being young at heart while subject to life’s new aches and pains. Stoppard’s playful, bawdy and heartbreakingly funny adaptation showcases his gift for comedy and intelligent dialogue, and won the prestigious Olivier Award for Best New Comedy in 2004. Tickets are $20 – $38 and are available online at lanterntheater.org or by calling the Lantern Box Office at 215-829-0395. $10 student rush tickets are available 10 minutes before curtain with valid ID; cash only. Additional discounts are available for seniors, groups of 10 or more, and current/former members of the U.S. military. Lantern Theater Company is located at St. Stephen’s Theater, 10th & Ludlow Streets in Center City Philadelphia.

As it continues to celebrate its own 90th birthday, Hedgerow Theatre is bringing together present and returning company members to stage Jane Austen’s ‘Pride and Prejudice,’ which marks its 200th anniversary this year, from May 9 to June 16. Jon Jory’s fast-moving adaptation of Austen’s 1813 classic captures all of the wit and romance in the brilliant comic novelist’s commentary on 19th-century British society. The nine-person cast features Hedgerow veterans Zoran Kovcic and Susan Wefel as Mr. and Mrs. Bennet, third-year company member Rebecca Cureton as Elizabeth Bennet, and returning company member Carl Smith, last seen at Hedgerow inGodspell, as Mr. Darcy. Also appearing in multiple roles are current Acting Fellows Mahogany Walker and Joel Guerrero, and returning actors Meredith Beck (‘Educating Rita’), Maryruth Stine (‘The Crucifer of Blood’) and Andrew Parcell (‘Deathtrap’). Smith and Beck also appeared together in the critically acclaimed ‘An American Tragedy.’ Pride and Prejudice is directed by the theatre’s Associate Artistic Director Jared Reed. Performances will be held Thursdays and Fridays at 7:30 p.m., Saturdays at 8 p.m., and Sundays at 2 p.m. through June 16. Adult ticket prices for Friday, Saturday and Sunday shows are $32, Thursday shows are $29, and Wednesday matinees are $25. There is a $3 discount for seniors; tickets for students with valid ID and children under 18 are $10. Previews are $20, and no other discounts apply. For groups of 10 or more, tickets are $18 for adults and $16 for seniors. Prices include all fees and are subject to change. For reservations, call 610-565-4211, or visit www.hedgerowtheatre.org. Hedgerow Theatre, America’s First Repertory Theatre, is at 64 Rose Valley Road, in Rose Valley (near Media).

The Delaware Valley Opera Company hired a chamber orchestra for Mozart’s ‘The Marriage of Figaro,’ their first production of the 2013 Summer Festival! The Marriage of Figaro is a real crowd-pleaser. Opera fans love the infectious melodies, and even newcomers will recognize some of the tunes from films and TV. Fans thrill over every gorgeously spun note in each aria and every twist of a musical line in the ensembles. Newbies are pleased to discover that opera can be funny. This tale is truly worthy of a sit-com. Figaro and his fiancee Susanna are servants to the Count and Countess Almaviva. With days to go before their wedding, Susanna and Figaro realize that the Count’s roving eyes have fallen on Susanna. The Countess has noticed, too. Tired of her husband’s philandering, the Countess concocts a scheme with Susanna to catch the Count in the act once and for all. And along the way there are plenty of mishaps, moments of mistaken identity, and disguises. DVOC presents The Marriage of Figaro in Italian with supertitles on June 15 and 19 at 8 p.m. at Stage One, 101 Plush Mill Road, Wallingford, Pa. 19086. For directions, please go to www.pacofdelco.org, or call 610-565-2110. For more details about DVOC’s 2013 Summer Festival, go to www.dvopera.org.

After breaking box office records and selling out in record time in 2010, ‘Wicked,’ Broadway’s biggest blockbuster, will return to the Academy of Music beginning June 26 – August 4 as part of the Broadway Season, presented by The Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts. With music and lyrics by Stephen Schwartz (Godspell, Pippin, Academy Award-winner for Pocahontas and The Prince of Egypt) and book by Winnie Holzman (‘My So Called Life,’ ‘Once And Again’ and ‘thirtysomething’), ‘Wicked,’ the untold story of the witches of Oz, is directed by two-time Tony-Award winner Joe Mantello and features musical staging by Tony-Award winner Wayne Cilento. Based on the best-selling 1995 novel by Gregory Maguire, ‘Wicked,’ winner of 35 major awards, including a Grammy and three Tony Awards, is the untold story of the witches of Oz. It is produced by Marc Platt, Jon B. Platt and David Stone. Tickets starting at $40 are on sale now and can be purchased by calling 215-731-3333, online at kimmelcenter.org/broadway, at the Kimmel Center box office, Broad & Spruce Sts. (open daily 10 am to 6 pm) or at the Academy of Music box office, Broad & Locust Sts. (open during performances only). Groups of 20 or more will receive discounts for select performances by calling 215-790-5883 or 866-276-2947. Performances include: Tuesday – Thursday evening at 7:30 pm; Friday & Saturday evening at 8:00 pm; Sunday evening at 6:30 pm; matinees Saturday at 2:00 pm and Sunday at 1:00 pm. Additional weekday performances will include: Thursday, June 27 at 2 pm and Monday, July 1 at 7:30 pm. No performances are scheduled for Thursday, July 4.
